data.text: Taking the Bike into the Hotel Room when Credit Card Touring

When "credit card" touring. Ehat do you do with your bike? I have hear some people actualy have the bike in the hotel room. How do you achieve that? what do you say? Ever been turn away because of the bike ? J
Yes! Bike in hotel room. Go to desk (with bike in tow), pay for room, take bike to room. Shut door and enjoy!
data.author: Angela M Freeman

data.text: In the UK, Travelodge & Premier inn allow bike's in your room, but they ask that bike's be clean.
data.author: Graham Minshall

data.text: I bring my bike into my room no matter what. Even if they have storage available
data.author: Dylan Buffalopine Serpentplume

data.text: Yeah, in the UK Premier Inn and Travelodge allow it and are fine with it. In South East Asia we have always taken our bikes in the room though sometimes needed to convince them it was OK but we found the best thing to do is just act normal about it, and go ahead like you've done it all before. When you doubt, they doubt.
data.author: Sarah Vickers

data.text: If I can't bring my bike in my room, I stay somewhere else
data.author: Scout Ess

data.text: Been in Portugal and Spain so far, hostel, hotel and airbnb, eather some kind of indoor storage, or in the room if storage is not available, I always ask first, noone said no so far. Sometimes it's a bit hard with narrow stairs or really small elevators, that's the only problem we have had
data.author: Patricia Larsson

data.text: I always email ahead, it's rarely a problem, but having the email reply means I don't need to worry about it. Obviously you usually have to lift the front of the bike to get it in the lift, but it's no issue.
data.author: Huw Mundy

data.text: We were not allowed to take the bikes in the room in Bremen. Luckily there was a safe bike storage nearby. Also in Stockholm it is not possible...
data.author: Karen Donckers

data.text: Only been knocked back once, but they secured it in their garage for me instead
data.author: Cliff Weier

data.text: I don’t stay in hotels a lot but only been turned down once. I agreed to lock it up outside. Paid for my room and took the bike inside the room.
data.author: Ty Dawley

data.text: If the nirel wants me & my money they want my bike. Of course you need to show some respect like not using towels/washcloths as bike cleaning rags and only lean your bike against a wall or solid furniture.
data.author: Rick Hancock

data.text: I've always taken my bike inside with out asking and no one has ever said anything to me.
data.author: Shane Daly

data.text: No problem so far, they want to get paid.
data.author: Dan Hurley

data.text: No dirtier than a pair of shoes and I don't ride the bike round the room.
data.author: Simon Tomkins

data.text: We always take our bikes in when we get a hotel room. If the receptionist hesitates when we ask we offer to carry them and they always say okay. Honestly, if anyone ever refused and we’d already paid/had no other options we’d do it anyway by either using a back door or just rolling right through the lobby and ignoring protests. Our bikes are way too important and expensive to be left vulnerable, even if they’d otherwise be locked on the car. They also don’t make half the mess that people’s spawn do.
data.author: Hunter Blackthorne

data.text: I am doing a tour on Katy Trail in MO in Fall. Camping in tent but got a hotel beside the trail in Jefferson City, MO. They said it's fine to keep bikes in rooms and everyone does it. I suppose you can ask before you book it.
data.author: Robert Zehr

data.text: In all fairness, any hotelier who runs a hotel near the Katy Trail that does not bend over backwards to keep cycle tourists happy is a moron and probably won't be in the business for long. That said, I have been on many trips with my bike and just wheel it into the room without even asking (it never really occurred to me to ask) and have never had a problem. As far as I am concerned, it is luggage and would be akin to telling me I couldn't keep golf clubs in my room. This has only been in the U.S., however, and my bike has always been reasonably clean looking. Tires on a road bike are likely not any more dirty than the wheels on roller suitcases after all.
data.author: Justin Stephen

data.text: I’ve never had an issue in the US. I always bring it in the room and never ask. Nobody has ever said anything either.
data.author: Nick Johnson

data.text: No bike in the room is a game stopper for me. Will find someplace else to stay. I ask before checking in.
data.author: John Goldman

data.text: In the US, hotel room. In Europe there is almost always a secure bike facility.
data.author: Tom Etheridge

data.text: agreed. That's what we've always found, too.
data.author: Anne Epplin Jesse

data.text: Just finished the Southern Tier in the U.S. Never had a problem with any hotel keeping my bike in a room. For the record, if a hotel refused I wouldn't stay there.
data.author: John Boyle

data.text: I wouldn’t leave my bike out. My friends have had very expensive bikes stolen. Get a ground floor room and bring the bike in.
data.author: Nancy DeCarlo Snider

data.text: Slightly different but my ferry gets in just before midnight so am staying at a travelodge near the ferry. I emailed them asking if they had secure bike storage or if I can take my bike in my room. They said I am allowed to have it my room so have printed off their email and will take it with me if I have problems.
data.author: Theresa Finking

data.text: good plan
data.author: Julian Young

data.text: travelodge and Premier Inn both allow you to take your bike into your room, no problem at all, in fact Premier Inn state this on their website. 👍
data.author: Jason Norman

data.text: that really is brilliant. Thanks for sharing.
data.author: Theresa Finking

data.text: Bike in hotel room. Absolutely. I only got told once that I couldn't. In Bruges. I asked the receptionist for three bin liners and put each wheel in one and the frame in the third, and called it "luggage". It went in my room. :-)
data.author: Michael Bryant

data.text: 🤣🤣🤣🤣🤣 love it
data.author: Julian Young

data.text: As bike trekking becomes more popular it should be a no brainer that some accommodation is made. But assuming storage is available or being allowed to take your bike into their hotel may be presumptuous. Ask when making your plans and as one suggested in a earlier post get the approval/acknowledgement in writing and have a copy with you when you check in. At least you know that you are covered. And if the hotel says no when you are booking, let them know you'll be booking elsewhere. It's a pretty competitive world out there and if they feel that your money is not suitable because it came in on two wheels well too bad for them.
data.author: James Murray Scott

data.text: Most hotels have a storing facility for bikes
data.author: Francois Swanepoel

data.text: Bike in room always - we've been sleeping together for years
data.author: Kelcy Pegler

data.text: We just walk in to the hotel with ours- usually at a Hampton or similar. Sometimes we ask, we’ve never been turned away. I don’t think it is much different than rolling a suitcase across the parking lot and bringing it in.
data.author: Tish Zimmerman

data.text: I toured last summer Seattle to Boston. Out of 75 nights, I was turned away once (snuck it in after hours).
data.author: Radfield Justice

data.text: Yes most hotels will turn you away. Some may have a lockup area but BnB’s are easier for touring. I like camping the best because you stay with your bike 🚴
data.author: Rachel Kuiper-Corbett

data.text: The bike is no different than bringing in your belongings in a suitcase with two wheels. ( I’ve never been asked but that is what I would argue)
data.author: Luis David Rojas

data.text: In Canada it is not a problem to have a bike in the room or in locked hotel storage. Ask first but most will do it. We tour and never camp - to old and spoiled for camping
data.author: Tracy Murray Estes

data.text: I’ve gone touring and camping and I have done motels/hotels. The bike always comes to the room with me. I’ve even taken it into grocery stores in a few cases. Personally, I never leave my bike alone.
data.author: Donald Ewen

data.text: I think most people just wheel them in after check in. I've never had a problem.
data.author: Mike Wallach

data.text: Most hotels in Canada and the US are fine. Some have me put it in storage. I was unfortunate enough to stay at a hostel in LA without either, needless to say my bike was missing by the 3rd night
data.author: Shane Peebles

data.text: 1.You roll or carry the bike thru the lobby . 2.Carefully load in elevator or roll down hall to your room . 3.Unlock door and place bike in room . There u go good luck
data.author: David Kfrerer

data.text: I always take the bike in the room. Never had a problem. No questions asked.
data.author: Steve Farmer

data.text: I placed my velomobile in the hallway. And the next Day they told me they had a room for cyclist.but i came late so i whas still lucky the system gave me a room on the floor level. And this where in germany.
data.author: Mark van Parkeerbeheer

data.text: Bike allowed in room or I’m not coming. Many dozens of nights so far with no problem.
data.author: Jeff Osborn

data.text: I’ve always just asked. Twice doing the GAP/C&O. Both times they said yes. Once they asked me to wash it off.
data.author: Tim Duffy

data.text: I have brought a bike into a hotel room. The only time I was turned away they offered to put the bike in the office or the utility closet
data.author: Meghan Bridget

data.text: did you store it there and stay at that place?
data.author: Michael Murphy

data.text: I did. They locked the room for me so I wasn't worried.
data.author: Meghan Bridget

data.text: Bikes in the room. We usually ask for a ground floor room to make it easier. 🇨🇦
data.author: Mike Hess

data.text: Never had any problems with bringing the bike in the room with me- it sleeps where I sleep. End of story.
data.author: Pete Bloom
Joe Mellady

data.text: No problem bringing bike into a hotel room. Some old buildings have an elevator which requires holding the bike vertically to fit it in. Some riders request a first floor room. Some hotels will gladly give you old towels to clean your bike or to put under the bike so not to dirty carpet. I have done this in 5-star hotels and 1-star hotels
data.author: Gary Bicycles

data.text: Bring it in. I'm always careful to not bring in mud or sand/gravel.
data.author: Lu Cornwell

data.text: I only stay in hotels that allow me to bring my bike in the room - never had an issue.
data.author: John Youker

data.text: I always book places where can take bikes inside or have secure storage
data.author: Sally Lloyd

data.text: Yeah, all UK Premier Inns allow bikes in rooms
data.author: Jon France

data.text: I pay for the room first, usually asking for one on the ground floor. Then just wheel the bike in smiling and smooth like you do it all the time. With our small wheeled Bike Fridays we flip them up nose first panniers and all in small elevators in Europe and China. Also there may be a side door in your hotel. In China we wheeled our bikes right up to the check in counter. My bike and I stay together. Don’t make a fuss, smile, be quick about getting out of public spaces, hallways etc. once in your room don’t soil towels or furniture with bike oil etc. say thank you on leaving. I always leave a tip, too.
data.author: Richard Mitchell

data.text: I stayed at International Hall in central London, booked through University Rooms, twice. The first time they reluctantly let us use their secure bike shed right by the entrance but we had to pay £5 each for two nights. The second time they refused but luckily we could leave them with my sister nearby. University Rooms is a great resource for cheap London accommodation, often with a good breakfast included, but check first about bike storage (for when the uni is closed to students).
data.author: Jon France

data.text: thanks great tip, can you book in advance? I guess you could ashk then
data.author: Julian Young

data.text: yes there’s a website called University Rooms which is for booking uni rooms all over the UK. Nice rooms, cheaper than hotels, well located.
data.author: Jon France

data.text:
Julian https://www.universityrooms.com/en-GB/
bookings for everyone
universityrooms.com
data.author: Jon France

data.text: Just take it in!
data.author: Robin Sparer

data.text: I usually ask if it's a internal access room, doors on the outside should never be problem. As someone else said it's no different than pulling a suitcase with wheels. Now bike should be cleanish and don't use the towels to clean the chain, I got warned at one place and I don't blame them. This is in the US.
data.author: Eric Smith

data.text: I stay in 2 and 3-star hotels that always allow me to bring my bicycle into the room. As a courtesy, I lift it up, rather than roll it, through the hallways.
data.author: Tom Montalbano

data.text: Apparently the secret is to CARRY the bike into reception and then carry it to the lift. Makes a huge difference, apparently. It magically changes from a vehicle into a personal effect in the eyes of the staff.
data.author: Jon Mathias

data.text: Always in the room. No exceptions. Had a hotelier on a rainy day ask us to wipe down the bikes, and obligingly handed us a roll of paper towels, which we happily did. That would be a good one to volunteer, as grimy drivetrain grease is way above the paygrade of the cleaners.
data.author: Ken Hill

data.text: Ibis budget in nantes suggested I take my bike to the room. Elevator rodeo
data.author: Heather Burles

data.text: I just book hotels that allow bikes, prior prep and planning etc
data.author: Andy McMahon

data.text: It’s not like your bringing an animal into your room. Some hotels host cycling events. It shouldn’t be an issue.
data.author: Joel Drubin

data.text: No I mainly cycle alone and don't bing my friends.
data.author: Julian Young

data.text: Sorry that was too good to pass up.
data.author: Julian Young

data.text: I have never been turned away because of the bike I have actually been helped by a motel that didn’t have room they got me an Uber to take me somewhere where I could stay that night cause I had gotten drenched and everything I had was wet it came back the next day and did laundry cost me 20 bucks at the motel but I got it done and I moved on I was so glad I didn’t have to sleep in wet clothes I went to Ortlieb panniers and haven’t had any trouble since with the money I spent that night I could’ve bought one set of bags I have a front and rear set and a duffel bag for the back of the cooler in front on top my rig weighs 360 driving over the elevator scale a lot of my extra weight is age related due to Health needs etc.￼￼￼￼￼￼
data.author: Fredrick Sullivan

data.text: The hotel usually has a storage room where you can store your bike. I’ve just completed a 14 day tour in France and we were able to store our bikes every night!
data.author: Bob Taylor

data.text: Interesting comments from people. I've gotten an impression from people where I live that they're to stay outdoors or in a shed, but this was in private accommodation from landlords (and in some workplaces) rather than hotels, etc. so can't comment. Just wondering what about marks/oil/etc. getting on the walls or floor from a bike?
data.author: Deirdre Clifford

data.text: Only done it twice but asked first. Not a problem.
data.author: Keith Brown

data.text: Always take our bikes to room. Never questioned
data.author: Vicki Moseley

data.text: I always call ahead and they usually have a place for bikes. If not I just ask to bring it into one of their staff rooms or living spaces and lock it up inside (at least it’s under camera supervision then)
data.author: Alex Sidney

data.text: Bring the bike through the window...bribe the staff
data.author: Silvio Suarez

data.text: Travelodge always let you take bike into room in my experience, B&Bs always have a spot to put your bike somewhere safe
data.author: Mark Randlesome

data.text: Don't ask just take it in. I was told in Moab not take my bike to my room. All I said was are you going to be responsible if something happened to it in your storage. Then I toolkit to my room.
data.author: George Toal

data.text: Guess it depends on the room? When touring Germany staying at guest houses, left bike locked up out side, motels/hotels I brought it inside
data.author: Clinton Mason

data.text: If you ever read any of the excellent and hilariously funny bicycle touring books by Tim Moore, he recounts many of his bike storage issues with hotels. Quite a lot of both chains and individuals will happily let you bring your bike in to your hotel room, but some won’t. His books are a go-to for anybody planning extended solo touring.￼
data.author: John O'Connell

data.text: We asked nicely, and tried to make sure we left no grease! 🤣
data.author: Cam Milleson
